content.micro: The cybersecurity strategy of the United States Government is executed along five lines of effort.

content.brief: The Federal workforce is the Government’s first line of defense in protecting the people’s information. Through the Federal Government’s Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy we are leveraging targeted education, training and exercises; improved recruiting and hiring practices; retention and development of highly skilled talent; and innovative best practices to heighten cyber risk awareness, that will help our workforce become “hard targets” that understand their roles and responsibilities and techniques that properly employ best practices to better protect the people’s information. The desired target state is a culture where every employee recognizes the criticality of protecting information and their role in cyber risk management.

The best practice of treating information as an asset is something we in the Federal Government recognize and are incorporating into our risk-based approach to cybersecurity. By treating information as an asset, we get a better understanding of the value of our information and adjusting our defenses so that we proportionally protect our high value assets. We need to treat information as an asset, perform asset valuations, and align our defense appropriate to the risk.

articles.title: Do the Right Things the Right Way
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: In the Federal Government, we are focusing attention on “buying down our cyber risk” by implementing best practices that do the right things the right way at the right time. For example, to better manage our networks, we are implementing the Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation program. When fully implemented, this capability will give us positive control of our networks and give us real-time visibility into what’s on our network, who’s on our network, and what’s going on in our networks.

The most successful organizations are the ones that are constantly challenging their own limitations. Constant innovation and wise investment will allow federal agencies to improve systematically instead of sporadically and unevenly, providing a smoother, more effective path to tighter, secure IT systems. Looking to the future, we need to build a modern enterprise architecture that enables us to securely and affordably deliver a more open and transparent government. We need to deliver cloud and mobility solutions that enhance productivity yet have security “baked in,” not bolted on as an afterthought. Across all departments and agencies, we need to give our senior leaders the actionable business case information they need to plan, program and budget so that we can rapidly deliver innovative solutions that are effective, efficient, and secure.

articles.title: Make Informed Cyber Risk Decisions at the Right Level
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Decision makers need the facts so they can make the best decisions possible to manage cyber risk. In the past, most cybersecurity decisions were made in the server room. Today’s environment calls for informed decisions to be made at the right levels based on a clearly-articulated risk management construct. A risk that can’t be articulated and measured won’t get addressed properly.

content.micro: In addition to applying the principles from the tips for home users, these steps can be used to help secure your organization.

articles.title: Limit Administrative Privileges and Access to Data
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Only allow information technology or helpdesk employees to install programs on machines to prevent users from accidentally or intentionally installing malicious software. Preventing employees from accessing information, unless they need it to fulfill their duties, reduces the available avenues for that data to be compromised. When employees leave, or change roles within the same organization, ensure that their accounts are removed or their privileges are updated.
Implement mandatory cybersecurity training to remind your employees to be vigilant when using the internet. Teach them how to spot phishing attempts and other common techniques used by hackers.

Require users to password protect their devices and encrypt their data, and automatically lock the device if inactive for a certain duration. If technology permits, establish policies for remote wiping of laptops and smart phones in case the device falls into the wrong hands.

When old hard drives or other forms of media are being disposed of, ensure that it is appropriately destroyed or sanitized to protect any corporate or personal data from being recovered from the disposed of media.

Consider requiring the use of virtual private network software, which facilitates secure information transfer between offices and servers, and allows employees working off-site to more safely use public Wi-Fi.

Cybersecurity insurance is designed to mitigate losses from a variety of cyber incidents, including data breaches, business interruption, and network damage, and may be a valid option for your organization when proper best practices fail.

content.micro: Use the resources below to report cyber incidents to the appropriate authorities. If you or someone else is in immediate danger, please call 911 or local police.

articles.title: Report a Cyber Incident
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: National Cybersecurity and Communications Integration Center

content.brief: If you believe you or your organization has been the victim of a cybersecurity incident, please report the incident to the Department of Homeland Security through these reporting forms.
If you believe you or your organization is the victim of ransomware, internet fraud, or other cybercrime, file a report to the Federal Bureau of Investigation using this form.

content.micro: The resources below provide guidelines on how to handle cybersecurity incidents.

content.brief: Ready.gov is a national Public Service Announcement designed to educate and empower Americans to prepare for and respond to emergencies. This resource includes information on what to do before, during, and after a cyber incident.

articles.title: NIST Computer Security Incident Handling Guide
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Recommendations of the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) assisting organizations in establishing computer security incident response capabilities and handling incidents efficiently and effectively. This publication provides guidelines for incident handling, particularly for analyzing incident-related data and determining the appropriate response to each incident.

content.micro: Resources that can be used to find cybersecurity job opportunities in the Federal Government.

content.brief: CyberCareers.gov is the Federal Government's official one-stop source for Federal cybersecurity job postings and employment information.
USAJOBS is the Federal Government's official one-stop source for Federal job postings and employment information.

content.micro:
Taking bold actions to protect Americans in today’s digital world. 

From buying products to running businesses to finding directions to communicating with the people we love, an online world has fundamentally reshaped our daily lives.  But just as the continually evolving digital age presents boundless opportunities for our economy, our businesses, and our people, it also presents a new generation of threats that we must adapt to meet.  Criminals, terrorists, and countries who wish to do us harm have all realized that attacking us online is often easier than attacking us in person.  As more and more sensitive data is stored online, the consequences of those attacks grow more significant each year.  

Meeting these new threats is necessary and within our grasp.  But it requires a bold reassessment of the way we approach security in the digital age.  If we’re going to be connected, we need to be protected.  We need to join together—Government, businesses, and individuals—to sustain the spirit that has always made America great. 

The Cybersecurity National Action Plan (CNAP) is the capstone of more than seven years of determined effort, building upon lessons learned from cybersecurity trends, threats, and intrusions.  This plan directs the Federal Government to take bold action and fosters the conditions required for long-term improvements in our approach to cybersecurity across the Federal Government, the private sector, and our personal lives.

content.brief: Read the complete announcement for the Cybersecurity National Action Plan on the White House blog.

articles.title: Cybersecurity National Action Plan Fact Sheet
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Read about the initiatives of the Cybersecurity National Action Plan.

content.micro: Angelina Jolie educate celebrate global network cooperation, public.
The Chief Information Security Officers (CISO) Council is the principal inter-agency forum uniting agencies’ efforts to strengthen the cybersecurity posture of the United States Government.

content.brief:
The CISO Council seeks to improve and enhance the cybersecurity posture of the United States by:

  • promoting the identification, development, and promotion of best practices;
  • instilling shared situational awareness and threat identification;
  • developing and promulgating information security policy;
  • improving strategic hiring and training of cybersecurity professionals;
  • encouraging implementation of shared services; and
  • providing professional development for cybersecurity professionals.

content.micro: In accordance with the Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014 (FISMA), the annual report provides Congress and the public information on agency progress towards meeting cybersecurity performance goals and identifies areas in need of improvement. This report also provides information on Federal cybersecurity incidents, ongoing efforts to mitigate and prevent future incidents, and agencies’ progress in implementing cybersecurity policies and programs to protect their systems, networks, and data.

content.brief: This report covers agency cybersecurity performance throughout fiscal year 2014-2015.

content.micro: Established by the Government Performance and Results Modernization Act (GPRA) of 2010, the Cross-Agency Priority (CAP) Goals aim to accelerate progress on a limited number of Presidential priority areas where implementation requires active collaboration between multiple agencies. The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) Cyber and National Security Unit, in partnership with the National Security Council (NSC), Department of Homeland Security (DHS), and Department of Defense (DoD), drives implementation of the cybersecurity CAP Goal amongst the federal agencies. This CAP Goal has a mission statement of, “Improve cybersecurity performance through ongoing awareness of information security, vulnerabilities, and threats impacting the operating information environment, ensuring that only authorized users have access to resources and information; and the implementation of technologies and processes that reduce the risk of malware.”

content.brief: Performance.gov is a part of the Administration’s efforts to deliver a more effective, smarter, and leaner government through transparent reports and metrics which track agency progress towards meeting the CAP Goals.

content.micro: The following resources will help you to recover from a cybersecurity incident.

articles.title: Recovering from a Trojan Horse or Virus
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: This step-by-step guide will help you return your computer to working order in the event of a Trojan horse, virus, or similar incident.
If one or more of your online accounts have been compromised or hacked, this guide provides steps that can help you to regain control.

If you believe you are a victim of identity theft as a result of a cybersecurity incident, report the incident to the Federal Trade Commission and find steps you can take to recover and prevent further damage from identity theft.

content.micro: These resources provide additional guidelines on how to prevent future cybersecurity incidents.

articles.title: Best Practices for Home and Business Users
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: A collection of tips that you can follow to help you or your organization safely and responsibly navigate in an increasingly connected world

articles.title: Protect Yourself and Your Organization from Ransomware

content.brief: This guide provides a series of steps that can be taken to help prevent ransomware, and prepare for what to do when it occurs.

Ready.gov is a national Public Service Announcement designed to educate and empower Americans to prepare for and respond to emergencies. This resource includes information on what to do before, during, and after a cyber incident.

content.micro: For more tips on protecting yourself or your organization, see the resources below.

articles.title: Good Security Habits
articles.source: United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team

articles.title: General Tips
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team

articles.title: Top Ten Cybersecurity Tips for Small Business Owners
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

articles.title: Tips and Resources to Stay Safe Online
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.micro: The following links can be used to help you keep your computer clean and up to date.

content.brief: Many computer security vendors offer free computer security checks for your computer. This resource includes links to check your computer for known viruses, spyware, and more as well as discover if your computer is vulnerable to cyber attacks.

articles.title: Check If Your Browser is Out of Date – Whatbrowser.org
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Keeping your web browser up to date is critical to safely browsing the web. Use this resource to find out what browser you are using, and find out whether you can update to a newer and safer version.

content.micro: Information Technology (IT) shared services allows the government to cut costs, increase efficiency, and improve cybersecurity posture.

content.brief: General Service Administration (GSA) contracts help government mandates and guidelines for cybersecurity products, services, and solutions. We offer a customizable suite of products and services, including shared services, helping government enhance security while bringing systems into the 21st century. We continually improve how we deliver the best value in technology services to government.

articles.title: Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation Readiness and Planning Guide
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team (US-CERT)

content.brief: This document proposes practical considerations for departments and agencies to leverage when implementing the Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation (CDM) Program asset-based security capabilities.

The Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program (FedRAMP) is a government-wide program that provides a standardized approach to security assessment, authorization, and continuous monitoring for cloud products and services. FedRAMP uses a “do once, use many times” framework that saves on government costs, as well as both time and staff required to conduct redundant agency security assessments.

An upcoming authentication platform to make online interactions with the U.S. government simple, efficient and intuitive. This platform will be a service shared by agencies to streamline logging in and to allow the public to securely access personal information and federal government services.

content.micro: The following models and assessments evaluate your organization’s cybersecurity systems, policies, and defenses.

content.brief: The CRR is a no-cost, voluntary, non-technical assessment to evaluate an organization’s operational resilience and cybersecurity practices. The CRR may be conducted as a self-assessment or as an on-site assessment facilitated by DHS cybersecurity professionals.

CVSS sets out to provide a robust and useful scoring system for IT vulnerabilities that is fit for the future. Its development has been overseen by the CVSS Special Interest Group (SIG) with input from representatives of a broad range of industry sectors, from banking and finance to technology and academia.

The Baldrige Cybersecurity Excellence Builder is a self-assessment tool to help organizations better understand the effectiveness of their cybersecurity risk management efforts. It helps leaders of organizations identify opportunities for improvement based on their cybersecurity needs and objectives, as well as their larger organizational needs, objectives, and outcomes.

Based on the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Special Publication 800-61 Rev. 2, Computer Security Incident Handling Guide, the NCCIC Cyber Incident Scoring System is designed to provide a repeatable and consistent mechanism for objectively evaluating the risk of a cybersecurity incident from a nationwide perspective.

content.micro: Resources for students of all ages to help them jump start their career in cybersecurity or a related field.

content.brief: The National Science Foundation and National Security Agency sponsor summer cybersecurity camp experiences for students and teachers at the K-12 level. The goals of the program are to help all students understand correct and safe on-line behavior, increase diversity and interest in cybersecurity and careers in the cybersecurity workforce of the Nation, and improve teaching methods for delivering cybersecurity content in K-12 computer science curricula.

The National Science Foundation (NSF) provides comprehensive scholarships to undergraduate and graduate students in exchange for students commitment to serve in local, state or the Federal Government. The program focuses on increasing and strengthening the cadre of information assurance professionals that protect the government’s critical information.
Opportunities for students from high school to post-grad to jumpstart a career in the Intelligence Community (IC).

content.micro: Resources for educators of all grade levels to help their students become interested in and learn more about cybersecurity.

content.brief: The National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE), led by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST), is a partnership between government, academia, and the private sector focused on cybersecurity education, training, and workforce development. The mission of NICE is to energize and promote a robust network and an ecosystem of cybersecurity education, training, and workforce development.

The Department of Homeland Security provides funding to the Cyber Innovation Center, which provides free, online curriculum to K-12 educators through the National Integrated Cyber Education Research Center (NICERC). The goal of the Cyber Innovation Center is to advance academic outreach and workforce development.

articles.title: National Initiative for Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: The Department of Homeland Security’s (DHS) National Initiative For Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS) portal provides professional development opportunities for Middle and High School Teachers, as well as Summer Camp coordinators, to teach cybersecurity and other science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.

articles.title: Centers of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: The National Security Agency (NSA) and the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) jointly sponsor the National Centers of Academic Excellence in Cyber Defense (CAE-CD) program. The goal of the program is to reduce vulnerability in our national information infrastructure by promoting higher education and research in cyber defense and producing professionals with cyber defense expertise for the Nation.

content.micro: Webinars, classes, and other materials for cybersecurity awareness training.

articles.title: Education and Training Catalog – National initiative For Cybersecurity Careers and Studies (NICCS)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: The Department of Homeland Security provides a central location where cybersecurity employees across the Nation can find over 2,800 cybersecurity-related courses.

articles.title: Cybersecurity Training and Education – Department of Energy (DOE)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: The DOE Cybersecurity Awareness and Training (CSAT) program provides Departmental personnel with the knowledge and skills necessary to protect DOE information and information systems.

articles.title: Cyber Awareness Challenge – Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Training module designed to test cyber awareness capabilities with regards to safeguarding sensitive information in the course of routine government computer use, learning to spot insider threats, and how to maintain this awareness while using social networking, mobile devices, or working from home.

Training module to learn about various types of phishing through email, and how to spot the social engineering methods used by adversaries to deceive users into handing over data or additional access.

articles.title: Identifying and Safeguarding Personally Identifiable Information (PII) – Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Training module to learn about Personal Identifiable Information (PII), how it can be identified, and the precautions necessary in handling communications involving PII, in order to prevent its unintended leakage.

articles.title: Incident Response Best Practices – Office of Management and Budget
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: This resource provided by OMB for agency use, provides a high-level overview of the communication and coordination steps agencies should take upon determining a major incident has occurred, aligned with the National Response Framework.

articles.title: Federal Incident Notification Guidelines – US Computer Emergency Readiness Team (US-CERT)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: US-CERT acts as the federal information security incident center for the United States Federal Government per FISMA 2002. Agencies are required to notify and consult with US-CERT regarding information security incidents involving the information and information systems (managed by a federal agency, contractor, or other source) that support the operations and assets of the agency, using the following guidelines.

articles.title: Federal Security Operation Center (SOC) Best Practices – Office of Management and Budget
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Best practices and use cases for operating Federal Security Operation Centers (SOCs) with the goal of ensuring that consistent roles, responsibilities, policies, and procedures are employed across the Federal Government.

articles.title: Privacy Best Practices for Agencies – National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: A collection of relevant standards and guidelines for managing privacy programs and privacy risk at Federal agencies.

articles.title: Privacy Best Practices – Federal Privacy Council (FPC)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Resources related to international privacy, and managing privacy in the legislative and judicial branches of the Federal government.

articles.title: Privacy Recommendations for the Use of Cloud Computing by Federal Departments and Agencies – CIO Council
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: This paper recommends that Federal agencies recognize and consider the privacy rights of individuals, and that agencies identify and address the potential risks when using cloud computing.

content.micro: On July 12, 2016, the White House released the first-ever Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy, which details government-wide actions to identify, expand, recruit, develop, retain and sustain a capable and competent workforce to address complex and ever-evolving cyber threats.

content.brief: In 2016 we released the first ever Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy directing a series of actions to identify, recruit, develop, retain, and expand the pipeline of the best, brightest, and most diverse cybersecurity talent for Federal service and for our Nation. The strategy brings all levels of government together with private industry, academia, international partners, and the public, to raise the level of cybersecurity in both the public and private sectors; deter and disrupt adversary activities in cyberspace; improve capabilities for incident response and resilience; and enact legislation to both incentivize and remove legal barriers to cybersecurity threat information-sharing among private entities and between the private sector and the Government.
Read the full Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy.

The National Initiative for Cybersecurity Education (NICE) is developing the NICE Cybersecurity Workforce Framework (NCWF) as a reference resource designed to help organizations more effectively build and maintain cybersecurity talent by providing a common language to categorize and describe cybersecurity work.

articles.title: Information Technology Asset Management Practice Guide
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Provides a reference build of an information technology asset management solution, including descriptions of the architecture, all products used in the build and their individual configurations.

articles.title: Guidelines on Firewalls and Firewall Policy
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: National Institute of Standards and Technology

content.brief: Assist organizations in understanding the capabilities of firewall technologies and firewall policies, and provides practical guidance on developing firewall policies and selecting, configuring, testing, deploying, and managing firewalls.

articles.title: Recommended Practice for Patch Management of Control Systems
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: Industrial Control Systems Cyber Emergency Response Team

content.brief: Securing industrial control systems against the modern threat landscape requires well-planned and well-implemented strategies that will provide network defense teams a chance to quickly and effectively detect, counter, and expel an adversary. This paper presents seven strategies that can be implemented today to counter common exploitable weaknesses in “as-built” control systems.

articles.title: Guide to Enterprise Patch Management Technologies
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

content.brief: Assists organizations in understanding the basics of enterprise patch management technologies, explains the importance of patch management, examines the challenges inherent in performing patch management, and provides an overview of enterprise patch management technologies.

articles.title: Vetting the Security of Mobile Applications
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)

content.brief: To help mitigate the risks associated with mobile app vulnerabilities, organizations should develop security requirements that specify, for example, how data used by an app should be secured, the environment in which an app will be deployed, and the acceptable level of risk for an app. To help ensure that an app conforms to such requirements, a process for evaluating the security of apps should be performed.

articles.title: Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation Readiness and Planning Guide
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.source: United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team
articles.subtitle: Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation Readiness and Planning Guide for Asset-Based Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation Security Capabilities

content.brief: This document proposes practical considerations for departments and agencies to leverage when implementing the Continuous Diagnostics and Mitigation (CDM) Program asset-based security capabilities.

articles.title: Summary of Cybersecurity Best Practices Electronic Control Systems
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: This report contains the results and analysis of a review of best practices and observations in the field of cybersecurity involving electronic control systems across a variety of industry segments where the safety-of-life is concerned. This research provides relevant benchmarks that are essential to making strategic decisions over the next steps for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration’s research program.

articles.title: Government Mobile and Wireless Security Baseline
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: This document contains the mobile security baseline and explains its relationship to the Mobile Security Reference Architecture, the Mobile Computing Decision Framework, and other mobile security activities.
Open source guide on how to implement common PIV configurations at your organization.

articles.title: Best Practices for Privileged User PIV Authentication – National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Explains the need for multifactor PIV-based user authentication to take the place of password-based single-factor authentication for privileged users, and provides best practices for agencies implementing PIV authentication for privileged users.

articles.title: Guide to Enterprise Telework, Remote Access, and Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) Security – National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Assists organizations in mitigating the risks associated with the enterprise technologies used for telework, such as remote access servers, telework client devices (including bring your own device and contractor, business partner, and vendor-controlled client devices, also known as third-party-controlled devices), and remote access communications.

articles.title: Combating the Insider Threat –National Cybersecurity & Communications Integration Center (NCCIC)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: This guide acts as a springboard for organizations to consider policies and practices used to detect and deter the insider threat, recommending that organizations understand normal employee baseline behaviors and also ensure employees understand how they may be used as a conduit for others to obtain information.

articles.title: National Insider Threat Task Force Documents – National Counterintelligence and Security Center
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Collection of documents which include minimum standards for Insider Threat programs, as well as Committee on National Security Systems (CNSS) documents and Intelligence Community Standards (ICS) related to the insider threat.

articles.title: Cloud Computing Security Requirements Guide – Department of Defense (DoD)
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Outlines the security model by which the Department of Defense (DoD) leverages cloud computing along with the security controls and requirements necessary for using cloud-based solutions.

sections.title: Office of Management and Budget Policies

content.micro: The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) puts forth policy memorandums (M-memos) and circulars to provide instructions, information, guidance, rules, and/or background information on legislative or procedural matters to Federal agencies. Please note that this list should serve as a starting point, and should not be considered exhaustive.

articles.title: Circular A-130
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.subtitle: Managing Federal Information as a Strategic Resource (July 27, 2016)

content.brief: Establishes general policy for the planning, budgeting, governance, acquisition, and management of Federal information, personnel, equipment, funds, IT resources and supporting infrastructure and services.

articles.title: Memoranda M-16-04
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.subtitle: Cybersecurity Strategy and Implementation Plan (CSIP) for the Federal Civilian Government (October 30, 2015)

content.brief: Provides recommendations to address gaps and priorities resulting from a comprehensive review of Federal Government’s cybersecurity policies, procedures, and practices by the Cyber Sprint Team.

articles.title: Memoranda M-17-05
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.subtitle: Fiscal Year 2016 - 2017 Guidance on Federal Information Security and Privacy Management Requirements (November 4, 2016)

content.brief: Establishes current Administration information security priorities and provides agencies with fiscal year 2016-2017 Federal Information Security Modernization Act and Privacy Management reporting guidance and deadlines, as required by the Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014.

This Federal Cybersecurity Workforce Strategy details government-wide actions to identify, expand, recruit, develop, retain, and sustain a capable and competent workforce in key functional areas to address complex and ever-evolving cyber threats.

content.micro:
Should you identify a potential error on this website, including failure to include a significant resource relating to the responsibilities and practices for Federal agencies, or if you have encountered an accessibility problem, please email us at OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov. Although we are interested in your feedback and suggestions, please be aware that we may not be able to respond to all email inquiries.

If you choose to provide feedback or to report an issue with accessibility and you send us your personally identifiable information via email at OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov, we will only use that information to respond to your message. Please review the website’s privacy policy to learn more about how the Federal Privacy Council may use information sent to the Federal Privacy Council or collected via this website.

Cyber.gov is the website of the Office of Management and Budget’s Cyber and National Security Unit (OMB Cyber), the United States Chief Information Security Officer, and the Chief Information Security Officers Council. Cyber.gov serves as a central collection of cybersecurity tips, best practices, and other resources that inform the public on how to protect themselves from cybersecurity threats.

Most of the material on Cyber.gov website is created by Federal employees, and you may reproduce, publish or otherwise use it without permission consistent with the Copyright Act of 1976. Please consider appropriate citation to Cyber.gov as the source. Copyrighted materials may also appear on this website, or may be reached through a link on this website. Copyright and other intellectual property laws may apply to your use of those materials. Most images found on Cyber.gov were licensed for use by Cyber.gov from a stock photography service or other copyright holder, who may prohibit republication, retransmission, reproduction, or any other use of the images.

Protecting the privacy and security of individuals’ personal information is very important to us. We do not collect any information that directly identifies you when you visit Cyber.gov unless you choose to provide that information by contacting us. However, the website may collect a limited amount of information about your visit for the purposes of website analytics and customization. Please read this notice to understand what we do with the limited amount of information about your visit that we may collect.

content.brief:
We collect limited information about visits to Cyber.gov. This information is used to measure the number of visitors to the various sections of our website and to identify performance or problem areas. We also use this information to help us develop the site, analyze patterns of usage, and to make the site more useful. We do not share or sell visitor data for the purposes of advertising, marketing, or any other commercial purpose. This information is not used for associating search terms or patterns of site navigation with individual users. The information that is automatically collected and stored concerning your visit includes:

  • The domain from which you access the Internet (i.e., HHS.gov if you are connecting from a HHS account, or GMU.edu if you are connecting from George Mason University’s domain);
  • The date and time of your visit;
  • Your location, as approximated by GPS, and other sensors;
  • The type of device you used to access Cyber.gov (i.e., mobile or desktop);
  • The operating system of the device you used to access Cyber.gov;
  • The pages you visit on Cyber.gov;
  • The Internet address of the website you came from if it linked you directly to Cyber.gov; and
  • Any search terms that you may enter when searching Cyber.gov.

When you visit a website, its server may generate a piece of text known as a “cookie” to place on your device. The cookie, which is unique to your browser, allows the server to “remember” specific information about your visit while you are connected. There are two types of cookies – single session (temporary) and multi-session (persistent). Single session cookies last only as long as your Web browser is open. Once you close your browser, the session cookie disappears. Persistent cookies are stored on your device for longer periods. Both types of cookies create an identifier that is unique to your device. The Office of Management and Budget Memorandum M-10-22, Guidance for Online Use of Web Measurement and Customization Technologies, allows Federal entities to use both session and persistent cookies to improve the delivery of services.

  • Session Cookies: We may use session cookies for technical purposes, such as to allow better navigation through our site. These cookies let our server know that you are continuing a visit to our site. Our use of session cookies qualifies as “Usage Tier 1–Single Session,” as defined in the OMB M-10-22 guidance.
  • Persistent Cookies: We may use persistent cookies to understand the differences between new and returning visitors to Cyber.gov. Persistent cookies remain on your device between visits to our site until they expire or are removed by the user. Our use of persistent cookies qualifies as “Usage Tier 2–Multi-session without personally identifiable information,” as defined in the OMB M-10-22 guidance. The policy states, “This tier encompasses any use of multi-session Web measurement and customization technologies when no [personally identifiable information] is collected.” We do not use persistent cookies to collect personally identifiable information.

If you do not want to accept cookies, you can edit your browser’s options to stop accepting persistent cookies or to prompt you before accepting a cookie from the websites you visit. Here are instructions for how you can disable cookies and/or Google Demographic and Interests reports.

Cyber.gov participates in the U.S. Digital Analytics Program, (DAP) which utilizes a unified Google Analytics account for Federal agencies. This program helps Federal agencies understand how people find, access, and use government services online.

The DAP is a hosted shared service provided by the General Services Administration’s (GSA’s) Office of Citizen Services and Innovative Technologies, and the protocol and information collected are the same for all websites participating in the DAP. As a participant in GSA’s DAP program, this website’s Google Analytics traffic data is automatically reported to GSA.

Google Analytics is a third-party web measurement and customization technology as defined in OMB M-10-22 (PDF).

Here is how it works: Google Analytics sets one or more cookies on your computer so that it can recognize your computer if you visit the Cyber.gov website in the future. These cookies doe not collect personally identifiable information. This is considered a Tier 2 usage, as defined in the OMB guidance.

Google Analytics does not collect personally identifiable information through its cookies. The program does not track individuals and anonymizes the IP addresses of visitors. Common Questions about DAP (FAQ) provides more information about how IP addresses are anonymized. According to GSA’s Common Questions About DAP, “none of the federal government data tracked as part of the Data Analytics Program will be shared with or available to Google’s corporate advertising partners.”

A limited number of authorized individuals will have user accounts that will allow them to log in to the Google Analytics dashboard and view or run reports regarding visits to Cyber.gov and the other web metrics available from the DAP.

Visitors who choose to disable this web measurement tool will still have full access to Cyber.gov. While the details vary from browser to browser, most modern browsers can be set up to accept, reject, or request user intervention when a site asks to set a cookie.

You can view web metrics information at https://analytics.usa.gov/.

articles.title: Contacting the Office of the Federal Chief Information Security Officer about Cyber.gov

content.brief: Users of this website may send the Office of the Federal Chief Information Security Officer feedback or report an issue by sending an email to OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov. If you choose to send us your personally identifiable information, we will only use that information to respond to your message. We only share the information you give us with another government agency if your question relates to that agency, or as otherwise required by law. Cyber.gov never collects information or creates individual profiles for the purposes of advertising, marketing, or any other commercial purpose. When you contact us, any personally identifiable information you provide is voluntary. Please do not include sensitive personally identifiable information or other sensitive information in the content of your email.

We believe in the importance of protecting the privacy of children online. The Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) governs information gathered online from or about children under the age of 13. This site is not intended to solicit or collection information of any kind from children under age 13. If you believe that we have received information from a child under age 13, please contact us at OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov.
Write to the Cyber.gov team at: OMBCyber@omb.eop.gov.

content.micro: Legally binding orders issued by the President to direct Federal agencies and officials in their execution of congressionally established laws or policies. Please note that this list should serve as a starting point, and should not be considered exhaustive.

articles.title: Executive Order - 13587
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.subtitle: EO-13587: Structural Reforms to Improve the Security of Classified Networks and the Responsible Sharing and Safeguarding of Classified Information (October 7, 2011)

content.brief: Establishes the requirement that agencies implement an insider threat detection and prevention program with guidance and standards developed by the Insider Threat Task Force.

articles.title: Homeland Security Presidential Directive - 12
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.subtitle: HSPD-12: Policies for a Common Identification Standard for Federal Employees (August 27, 2004)

content.brief: Sets forth the requirement that Federal agencies implement a common reliable form of identity certification and access management to safeguard the Federal community, information, systems, and facilities.

articles.title: Presidential Policy Directive - 41
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.subtitle: PPD-41: United States Cyber Incident Coordination (July 26, 2016)

content.brief: Sets forth principles governing the Federal Government’s response to any cyber incident, whether involving government or private sector entities. For significant cyber incidents, this also establishes lead Federal agencies and an architecture for coordinating the broader Federal Government response.

sections.title: National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Standards

content.micro: Generally accepted guides by the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) that serve as a template or ideal standard for enterprise cybersecurity programs. Please note that this list should serve as a starting point, and should not be considered exhaustive.

content.brief: A voluntary risk-based Cybersecurity Framework, comprised of a set of industry standards and best practices to help organizations manage cybersecurity risks and protection of critical infrastructure in a cost-effective way based on business needs.

The National Institute of Standards and Technology's Special Publications 800 series provide guidelines, recommendations, and reference materials on cybersecurity, including topics such as risk management, security and privacy controls, Personal Identity Verification requirements, and incident response.

Federal Information Processing Standards Publications are public technical standards issued by the National Institute of Standards and Technology for use in information systems to ensure security and interoperability.

articles.title: The Cybersecurity Framework - Industry Resources
articles.source: National Institute of Standards and Technology

content.brief: This is a listing of publicly available resources including: approaches, methodologies, implementation guides, mappings to the National Institute of Standards and Technology Cybersecurity Framework, case studies, educational materials, Internet resource centers (e.g., blogs, document stores), example profiles, and other cybersecurity framework document templates.

articles.title: Best Practices for Home and Business Users
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: A collection of tips that you can follow to help you or your organization safely and responsibly navigate in an increasingly connected world

content.micro: There is no infallible way to guarantee your safety on the internet, but these tips can prevent you from being an easy target for hackers.

articles.title: Strong Authentication: Lock Down Your Login
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Many popular websites and services are offering strong authentication (also called multi-factor or two-factor authentication) in order to provide better security for your private information. This resource includes a list of popular online services which support strong authentication and links to step-by-step guides to enable this additional protection.

• Use different passwords for different accounts; If one password is compromised, hackers will only have access to one account rather than all of them. 
  • Use password phrases rather than words; passwords that consist of a collection of words are not only easier to remember but can be more difficult to hack. 
  • Use a password or similar feature to lock your mobile devices; Limiting access to your devices through such features prevents your information from being compromised if your devices are lost or stolen.
  • Choose answers to security or recovery questions that are difficult to research and only known to you; If you forget your password, these questions are used to reset your password. Questions with answers that can be found in public record or on your social media accounts may make it easier for hackers to hijack your online accounts.

articles.title: Use Anti-Viral Software
articles.source: United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team

content.brief: Anti-virus software scans files or your computer’s memory for certain patterns that may indicate the presence of malicious software (i.e., malware). Anti-virus software (sometimes more broadly referred to as anti-malware software) looks for patterns based on the signatures or definitions of known malware.

Firewalls provide protection against outside attackers by shielding your computer or network from malicious or unnecessary network traffic and preventing malicious software from accessing the network. Firewalls can be configured to block data from certain locations or applications while allowing relevant and necessary data through.

Software developers periodically release patches or updates that generally improve quality and security. Make sure your programs, web browsers, plugins, anti-virus software, and operating systems are up to date. Enable options to automatically download updates, if available, in order to reduce the amount of effort.

If you are not expecting an attachment from someone, do not open it. Hackers can send emails pretending to be from someone trustworthy, like a friend, family member, coworker, or the representative of a business or the government. Whenever possible, check with the sender through an alternative means of communication to ensure the attachment’s legitimacy.

Avoid storing files with personal information like social security numbers, credit card numbers, and passwords. If it is absolutely necessary to store this information digitally, make sure that information is encrypted or password protected.

Make a backup of documents, works, music, pictures, and other valuable files by making multiple electronic copies, periodically storing them on a USB drive, another computer you own, or on a cloud service. In the event of an attack or other catastrophic event, you can rest knowing that your work and memories are not lost forever.

Today’s home network may include a several wireless devices, from computers and phones, to smart TVs and connected appliances. Taking basic steps to encrypt and secure your home network will help protect your devices – and your information – from compromise.

Only provide personal information (like a credit card when shopping online) when the connection to the website is encrypted, or else your interaction with that website can be spied on or even hijacked. You can verify a website is encrypted by looking for "https" before the website address, which depending on your browser can be complemented by a lock symbol or green bar. Avoid using unencrypted websites when on public wireless hotspots, as they are particularly vulnerable to the snooping of hackers.

articles.title: Be Careful What You Post Online
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5

content.brief: Social media can be a useful tool to connect with friends and loved ones. However, providing valuable personal information like your birthdate, where you were born, and the name of your high school on social media lays the groundwork for nefarious actors to steal your identity. Posting statuses and pictures using geolocation features can be used to find you, or help potential thieves know that you aren’t at home. Use privacy options available within your social media to limit the visibility.

Smart phone users often download apps for one time use and then never use them again. To free up space and prevent information from being compromised, delete your unused apps. Use features on your phone’s operating system to find out what information your apps have access to, and when possible, limit what information it collects.

articles.title: Manage Your Bluetooth Devices
articles.source: United States Computer Emergency Readiness Team

content.brief: While Bluetooth technology can be fairly secure, by taking basic steps such as disabling Bluetooth when you are not actively using it, you can help protect yourself from hackers attempting to infiltrate your Bluetooth devices.

content.micro: Statute or laws as passed by the United States Congress as they relate to requirements placed on Federal agencies. Please note that this list should serve as a starting point, and should not be considered exhaustive.

content.brief: This bill aims to improve cybersecurity in the United States through enhanced sharing of information about cybersecurity threats, and for other purposes. The Cybersecurity Information Sharing Act of 2015 requires the Director of National Intelligence and the Departments of Homeland Security, Defense, and Justice to develop procedures to share cybersecurity threat information with private entities, nonfederal government agencies, state, tribal, and local governments, the public, and entities under threats.

articles.title: Federal Information Technology Acquisition Reform Act
articles.subtitle: FITARA (December 19, 2014)

content.brief: More commonly known as FITARA, Sec. 831-843 of the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2015 requires specified federal agencies to ensure that the Chief Information Officer of the agencies has specified authorities and responsibilities in planning, programming, budgeting, and executing processes related to information technology. FITARA also requires the Office of Management and Budget to make the cost, schedule, and performance data of specified information technology investments publicly available. Requires the Chief Information Officer of each agency to categorize the investments according to risk and review those that have a high level of risk.

articles.title: Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014
articles.author: 57ffa09e912367363e03a5b5
articles.subtitle: FISMA (December 18, 2014)

content.brief: Amends the Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 to reestablish the oversight authority of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget with respect to agency information security policies and practices, and sets forth authority for the Secretary of Homeland Security to administer the implementation of such policies and practices for information systems.
